metaDescription: Stunning 51m² apartment in Torrevieja from €195,000. Perfect retirement home with peaceful lifestyle, expat community & year-round sunshine.
heroIntro:
Welcome to your peaceful retirement sanctuary in Playa Del Cura, Torrevieja—one of Spain's most welcoming destinations for discerning expats seeking a relaxed lifestyle without compromise. This beautifully appointed 1-bedroom apartment offers exceptional value at €195,000 (€3,824/m²), representing 45% less than comparable properties in Costa Blanca North while maintaining premium specifications and finishes.

Torrevieja has become synonymous with quality of life for retirees, combining year-round sunshine, world-class healthcare, and a thriving international community where English is spoken everywhere. This isn't about settling for less—it's about making your retirement investment work smarter. With an 8% annual property appreciation trend and strong rental potential, your home becomes both a personal retreat and a sound financial decision.

Located in the heart of Playa Del Cura, you're mere steps from pristine Blue Flag beaches, excellent restaurants, and vibrant local markets. Imagine morning walks along golden sands, afternoon coffee at waterfront cafés, and evenings with friends from around the world—all underpinned by excellent healthcare facilities and the peace of mind that comes with living in Spain's largest expat community.
areaSection: Torrevieja sits on the stunning Costa Blanca coast in Alicante Province, blessed with 320 days of annual sunshine and a temperate Mediterranean climate that supports an outdoor lifestyle year-round. The town has transformed into a sophisticated coastal destination while retaining authentic Spanish charm. Just 50km south of Alicante city and 45 minutes from the airport, Torrevieja offers convenient access to the wider region without the overcrowding of northern Costa Blanca resorts. The natural harbor creates a picturesque seafront, while the nearby salt lakes (Las Salinas) add unique ecological interest. With a population balancing locals and internationals, Torrevieja has developed excellent infrastructure—modern hospitals, international schools, shopping centers, and transport links—making it genuinely livable rather than merely touristy.
lifestyleSection: Daily life in Torrevieja revolves around a relaxed Mediterranean rhythm perfectly suited to retirement. You'll find yourself joining the largest expat community in Spain—English is genuinely spoken everywhere, from supermarkets to medical clinics to restaurants. Healthcare is exceptional; you can consult English-speaking doctors at modern facilities like Hospital Universitario de Torrevieja or choose private clinics like Quirónsalud. Weekdays might include beach walks, coffee with friends at the paseo marítimo, or activities at one of four nearby championship golf courses. The weekly markets burst with fresh produce, while supermarkets like Mercadona and Carrefour stock familiar international products. Evenings offer outstanding dining—from paella at beachfront chiringuitos to international restaurants catering to the cosmopolitan community. You'll benefit from excellent bus connections to Alicante and Murcia, though most retirees find a car helpful for exploring hidden beaches, mountain villages, and regional attractions.

investmentSection: Beyond being your ideal retirement home, this property represents sound financial positioning. Torrevieja property values have appreciated 8% year-on-year, outpacing many European markets. At €3,824/m², this represents exceptional value compared to Costa Blanca North (which averages €6,500/m²) while maintaining premium specifications. The rental market proves robust—comparable apartments command €650 per week during peak seasons, generating €33,000 annually if you choose to rent part of the year. lifeAndAmenities.intro: Torrevieja excels in providing everyday conveniences expected by retirees and international residents. World-class healthcare, supermarkets stocking international products, restaurants serving every cuisine, and efficient public services create a genuinely comfortable living environment. English is widely spoken, administrative processes are well-established, and the expat community ensures you'll never feel isolated.

healthcare.text: Healthcare in Torrevieja consistently ranks among Spain's best. Hospital Universitario de Torrevieja is a modern, fully equipped public facility providing 24-hour emergency services, specialist consultants, and advanced diagnostics. Private alternative Quirónsalud Torrevieja offers rapid access and English-speaking specialists. Numerous private clinics throughout town employ English-speaking doctors and nurses, addressing everything from routine check-ups to complex conditions. Prescription medications are affordable through Spain's healthcare system. The substantial expat population means medical professionals are accustomed to treating international patients and explaining procedures in English. Many retirees maintain health insurance through Spain's public system (affordable for EU residents) or private insurance, both providing comprehensive coverage.

education.text: While retirement properties rarely focus on education, grandchildren visiting will find excellent international options. El Limonar International School offers British curriculum education with high academic standards. Colegio Internacional de Torrevieja provides alternative international programs. Both schools serve expat families and maintain strong reputations. Public Spanish schools are also available and well-regarded, with language support programs for international families. The presence of quality education options supports multi-generational visits and potentially younger family members relocating.

shopping.text: Shopping in Torrevieja combines Spanish local markets with international supermarket chains, ensuring you'll find everything you need. Mercadona operates multiple locations and stocks Spanish staples plus international products at competitive prices. Carrefour, Lidl, and Aldi provide additional variety and choice. Iceland supermarket specifically stocks British products popular with expat residents. The weekly markets (held throughout different neighborhoods) burst with fresh produce, fish, and local specialties at unbeatable prices. Torrevieja town center features shops, pharmacies, and boutiques. The cosmopolitan population means specialized dietary requirements and international brands are readily available.

transport.text: While Torrevieja lacks metro or tram systems, transport connectivity is excellent. Alicante-Elche Airport is 48km away (45-minute drive), with regular flights to UK and European cities. Regular bus services connect Torrevieja to Alicante city, Murcia, and coastal towns, providing affordable public transport. Most retirees appreciate owning a car for flexibility exploring beaches, villages, and regional attractions. Driving is straightforward with good road infrastructure. Parking throughout town is generally available. The compact layout of Playa Del Cura means many daily needs are within walking distance, reducing dependency on transport.

faqs.question: Is Torrevieja a good place to live?
faqs.answer: Yes. Torrevieja consistently ranks among Spain's best retirement destinations, combining year-round Mediterranean climate, world-class healthcare, and Spain's largest expat community where English is widely spoken. The town balances authentic Spanish culture with international infrastructure, excellent amenities, and genuine quality of life for retirees seeking outdoor, social, and active lifestyles.

faqs.question: How much does property cost in Torrevieja?
faqs.answer: Average property prices in Torrevieja are approximately €1,850/m², though beachfront locations like Playa Del Cura command premium prices reflecting superior views and proximity. A typical 1-bedroom apartment averages €150,000-€250,000. This property at €195,000 (€3,824/m²) reflects premium beachfront specifications while offering value compared to non-beachfront alternatives and significantly less than Costa Blanca North equivalents.

faqs.question: Is Torrevieja good for expats?
faqs.answer: Excellent. Torrevieja hosts Spain's largest expat community with well-established English-speaking networks, International schools, and medical professionals experienced with international residents. English is genuinely spoken in shops, restaurants, and businesses. Administrative processes are straightforward, and you'll find immediate social connections through established expat clubs, churches, and activity groups.

faqs.question: Are there English speaking doctors in Torrevieja?
faqs.answer: Yes. Hospital Universitario de Torrevieja, Quirónsalud Torrevieja, and numerous private clinics employ English-speaking medical professionals. Many doctors specifically list English fluency due to the substantial expat population. You can consult in English at specialist clinics, receive prescriptions in English, and access translated medical records without difficulty.

faqs.question: What is the weather like in Torrevieja?
faqs.answer: Exceptional. Torrevieja enjoys 320 days of annual sunshine with mild winters (12-17°C) and warm summers (26-32°C). The Mediterranean climate supports year-round outdoor activities, beach swimming (water temperature 14-27°C), and garden activities. Rainfall is minimal, typically 250-300mm annually. This consistent pleasant weather is a primary reason retirees choose Torrevieja over northern European climates.

faqs.question: How far is Torrevieja from Alicante airport?
faqs.answer: 48 kilometers, approximately 45 minutes driving via the AP-7 motorway. Regular flights connect Alicante to UK cities (London, Manchester, Glasgow, Edinburgh, Belfast) and throughout Europe. Car rental is straightforward, taxis/airport shuttles are available, and the journey is straightforward for retirees traveling to visit family or explore Europe.

faqs.question: Can I rent this apartment for income?
faqs.answer: Yes. Comparable apartments in Playa Del Cura typically generate €600-€700 weekly rental income during peak seasons (May-September). Annual gross rental potential for this property would be approximately €30,000-€35,000 if rented 7-8 months yearly. Many retirees use seasonal rental to offset property costs while maintaining personal use during winter months, making this both a home and income-generating asset.

faqs.question: What nationalities live in Torrevieja?
faqs.answer: Predominantly British, Dutch, German, and Scandinavian retirees form the expat core, with growing numbers from Eastern Europe, France, Belgium, and other EU nations. British residents comprise the largest single group. This diversity creates a cosmopolitan community with multiple languages spoken and international social activities, yet maintains authentic Spanish character in local neighborhoods and markets.

faqs.question: Is Torrevieja safe to live?
faqs.answer: Yes. Torrevieja maintains low crime rates compared to European averages, with visible police presence and professional security systems in most residential buildings. The established expat community means neighborhood associations, community watch groups, and well-maintained public spaces. Standard urban precautions (securing valuables, locking doors) apply, but residents generally feel secure living and walking around town.
